Ok, this might seem like a simple question, but I want to know the answer for ‘correctness’ so I can properly yell at my (seemingly poor) offshore resource. We have a method that returns an int, and need to convert it to a string, these what they have done is like so ```someClass.setSomeString(“” + otherClass.returnsInt());```
should they really be using String.Format(), or .toString on the int?
my presumption is String.Format, but I’m not all-knowing in java
Integer.toString() is ok i think
String.valueOf( T )
either or
I prefer valueOf
the concatenation is going to be more cycle-intense right?
iirc it translates to stringbuilder and back
so yes, a minor difference in performance
awesome thanks guys

text: <@U09T8SFG8>, yeah i agree. i think it’s the naming and re-purposing aspect of it. freaks me out a little bit.
any rx experts out there have an idea for how I can simplify this logic?
I have network calls A and B.  based on some boolean, I either need to perform A then B (with flatmap), or just B
right now I’m branching with the boolean at the method call, and it would be nice to combine into one method
<http://reactivex.io/documentation/operators/and-then-when.html>
would that help?
haven’t used and-then-when before though
I’ll check it out, thanks
damn, i've run into a bunch of situations where that would probably be useful
didn't know rxjava had additional modules :x
thanks for the link
<@U08KK98UU>: are each of your network calls their own observables?
yes
like public Observable<thing> doCallA()  { ..} ?
exactly
and you know your boolean before you do either like doAandB(boolean doA)
yea the boolean is already known before making either call
since right now I’m using it to branch between them
do you need info from A to do B or do they just need to be done in order
like does B need A’s response
I do pick some info out of A’s response, but it’s optional
if B sees that field empty it can still do its work
i’m looking at something one sec
no rush, I’m here all day :stuck_out_tongue:

text: guys, any idea? how to align a fragment to the centre while replacing in an activity (while Fragment Transaction)
<@U07DEGHHT|nickpontiff> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/nickpontiff/F0QV516US/-.java|Untitled> and commented: <@U08KK98UU>:

file.name: -.java
file.title: Untitled
file.preview:
public void doCall(final boolean doA) {

        Observable.just(new CallA().call(doA))
                  .flatMap(new CallB()).subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
                  .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
file.preview_highlight:
public void doCall(final boolean doA) {
​
        Observable.just(new CallA().call(doA))
                  .flatMap(new CallB()).subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
                  .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())

<@U0A0S0WG0>: tell me ur problem. Might be able to help now
trying to run a subprocess using Popen and get the exit code from the executable
Should be pretty simple
I’ve tried doing something along the lines of `p = subprocess.Popen(command, shell=True, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)`
and then `exitCode = p.communicate()[0]` and its just an empty string
Why not use subprocess.call?

<@U061HDV96>: hey sorry, i got pulled away right after I sent that to you. And to answer your question, I’ve been using Popen because thats whats in the rest of the code, but I honestly don’t know the difference
Alright, I'm back
Back at my apartment
Now I can take a closer look
It should just be the .returncode
But communicate needs to be called first it seems

```p = subprocess.Popen(['ls', '-la'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)
p.communicate()
exit_code = p.returncode```
But it is recommended not to use Popen
Popen is for advanced use
Then what you use depends on the Python version
subprocess.call() on Python 2 and subprocess.run() on Python 3
Also for Python 2, use subprocess32 instead
<https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0324/>
